answers.answer: and i forgot a stabbing pain under my left rib

I am so sorry to hear that you got such news, but it's not the end of the world.  I was diagnosed with Type II diabetes on my 40th birthday.  I am now 57.  I totally understand the feelings you are having.Most of the symptoms you describe COULD be caused by your blood sugar levels being off.  The pain in your ribs and in your back, needs to be looked at by a doctor.I found that the most important part of bringing my blood sugar levels down, was losing weight.  I have been overweight most of my life.  I went from being insulin dependent to just a pill every day, to control my levels.  That was after I lost 125 pounds.  I have kept 100 pounds off.I am a sweets lover, so to satisfy my sweet tooth, I found sugarless dessert products at the grocery store.  I also found that not eating breads, pasta, alot of cereals, etc., also helped to keep my levels down.  (Carbohydrates are a no-no, if your levels are too high.)  You can eat them in very small amounts, but you have to be careful how much you consume in one day.  I'm sure you already know all of this.You CAN live an active and healthy life, it just takes discipline, when you have diabetes.Please let a doctor know about your rib pain.I wish you the very best.Heatherfrom the MS Forum

question: i am a newly diagnosed diabetic , i was diagnosed xmas eve , and i feel unwell , i have a headache  light headedness , foggy, and a little dizziness and occasionally short of breath , i have pain across the bottom of my back going right up my back as an ache i also have acid reflux, i need to know if any of these symptoms are consistent of diabetes  , thx
title: are these symptoms consistent with diabetes
